childMarkdownRemark.html:
Craft activities

I hope you enjoy the activities I have chosen. I have decided to run this theme for two months as there are so many lovely nursery rhymes that craft can be linked to it. Some of the songs will differ between March and April with a Spring feel to April’s sessions. If this is the first time that you have received a pack please read the ‘Introduction to Buds and Blooms resource packs’ section prior to reading this. The photos of each activity are just to give you an idea of what each item can look like and to save you having to read through lots of instructions whilst trying to entertain your child. As explained in the ‘Introduction section’ please don’t worry about the end product.

Everything which is supplied is safe for young children as long as they are supervised at all times. Buds and Blooms can therefore not be held responsible for any accidents that result from using the resources provided. You may find that not all the activities are suitable for your child which is why a large range has been provided so that there is something for everyone.

Other than the Mother’s Day and Easter craft, all the items you make can be used as props during the sessions. If you get a chance it is worth reading through all the instructions before doing any of the activities as many of the materials are for several of the activities. I have included PVA glue which is best when gluing anything other than paper or card. The A4 pouch provided could be used to keep the props in so you have them all in one place and ready for the sessions.

Mother’s Day - The book ‘I love my Mummy’ is a gift for you and your child, to mark Mother’s Day.

Easter - As we will be unable to hold an Easter egg hunt again this year I will be sending out packs specifically for Easter which contain everything you need for an Easter egg hunt (excluding chocolate due to allergies and trying to send it through the post), a number of themed craft kits and some gifts for your child/ren.

Make your own Instruments - There are a number of easy to make instruments. I have included a few ideas below.

Decorate the plastic egg included in your pack with the sequins from the craft bumper pack. Place some uncooked rice or pasta inside, close the egg and use the decorative tape to secure the egg in case of little fingers trying to open them!

Decorate the outside of the paper plate from your pack using paint sticks or paint e.t.c. Leave to dry and then fold in half. Open the plate and use PVA glue to attach two plastic bottle tops (not included in your pack) opposite each other (so they are touching when you close the plate) which will click together when the plate is closed. Fold your castanet back in half again and hold it between your thumb and fingers to play.

You will need a disposable drinking bottle or washing up liquid bottle e.t.c and some uncooked rice or pasta. Put some rice or pasta in the bottom of the bottle and add some sequins from your pack to add a bit of colour. Decorate the outside of the bottle with foam shapes. Use the decorative tape to secure the lid of the bottle in case of little fingers trying to open them!
A set of five dinosaur puppets are included in your pack for use with one of the songs we will be learning.
Decorate the puppets using a variety of the materials from the craft bumper pack. When they are dry then attach the front to the back using PVA glue. Alternatively, if you prefer you could sew them.
There are a number of themed cardboard finger puppets to be coloured in which can then be used as props for the songs during the sessions.

Cut out the circles, attach each one to a plain lolly stick and write the rhyme along the stick. Use the bag supplied to store the sticks in. During the session there will be an opportunity for each child to choose one for us to sing.

Encourage your child to place the stickers in various positions on the scene. Use the scene as a talking point to help develop your child’s speech and language skills such as singing and commenting on particular rhymes.
Use the pack of felt and any of the materials from the craft bumper pack to make Humpty Dumpty. You could also decorate a small box to act as a wall when re-enacting the nursery rhyme.

activities.activityTitle: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 once I caught a fish alive

childMarkdownRemark.html: Use a variety of the materials from the craft bumper pack to decorate the fish.

activities.activityTitle: The Grand Old Duke of York

childMarkdownRemark.html: Use a variety of the materials from the craft bumper pack to decorate the flag.
Use a variety of the materials from the craft bumper pack and any surplus poster paint from previous packs to decorate the hand clapper.

Cut out and stick the flower pot onto the Mother’s Day card. Use some of A4 coloured card to draw around your child’s hand. Then cut it out and place it on the card above the flower pot. Do as many as you wish. Alternatively, you could paint your child's hand and make a print. It is best to do this on a separate sheet of paper and then cut them out and stick them on when they are dry.

Decorate the Easter shapes with the pack of small feathers, Easter stickers, and any surplus poster paint and paint sticks from previous packs. Use the card provided to stick them onto and there are envelopes provided if you wish to post any. If you know of anyone who lives alone in your street, how about making one for them, it doesn’t matter if you don’t know them but helps to reach out to those who may be lonely.
